title: EELS-Monitored AC-STEM-Fabrication of Sub-Nanometer Pores and Features in Hexagonal Boron Nitride and Correlated Photoluminescence and Ionic Transport Measurements
content: Creating sub-nanometer to few-nanometer defects and nanopores in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) opens new opportunities for realizing quantum emitters and for nanofluidic and sensing applications [1-6]. Using the electron beam in the aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscope (AC-STEM) we demonstrate modification, thinning and drilling of features in multilayer hBN (âˆ¼ 5-to-20-nm-thick). These processes are monitored with electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), revealing the atomic composition, and allowing for drift correction. We report effects of electron-beam energy and exposure times on defect size and structure.
